deck: Writer and Artist for FantaCo's Gore Shriek series, and publisher of underground mini-comics.
description:
Chas was among the early wave of underground mini-comics publishers, during the Clay Geerdes era, before mini-comics were so essential to the post-underground comix scenes in the 1980s. Chas was working with comix distributor George DiCaprio and their amigos on titles like Spaz Comix and Mighty High Comix. He self-published most of his work prior to his 1980s relationship with FantaCo.

Before his FantaCo years, Chas had the seminal The Connoisseur’s Guide to the Contemporary Horror Film under his belt, along with The Gore Score and the first issue of Deep Red (self-published with Chris Amouroux). FantaCo did well as one of Chas’s distributors, hustling copies of all Chas’s horror movie books via FantaCo’s growing mail-order outlet and major ad presence in Fangoria. Horror Holocaust was the first of Chas’s book FantaCo published, which led to Deep Red continuing and briefly flourishing, culminating in the Deep Red Alert and The Deep Red Horror Handbook. It was the Fantaco run on Deep Red that first brought Chas and I together, via my submitting capsule reviews to his excellent, attitude-packed zine. Chas was the first editor to cultivate my writing skills, and for that I owe him for life.

That said, Chas always found comics somewhat – daunting. “I tell you though, after I realized how long it took to draw a comic, that sort of turned me off to whole experience,” Chas says. “It took way, way too long. And comic books never pay dick. I’ve talked to Bernie Wrightson and he said, ‘Chas., I felt like I was really smoking if I could just ink a page a day.’ And at a time when people were paying between $40 and $100 a page… I mean jeeze! You might as well go mow lawns or wash cars or something! Drawing is just too hard. And there’s no way to do it quickly…”. That’s what Chas told John Szpunar on the Barrel Entertainment site

Taken from Steven Bissettes Gore Shriek Memories blog post: Link

IMDB Page: Link
name: Chas Balun

deck: writer and musician
description:
Best known as a musician, Tom Morello was born Thomas Baptiste "Tom" Morello  on May 30, 1964.
 
Bands he plays for are Rage Against The Machine, Audioslave and his solo project The Nightwatchman. Street Sweeper Social Club is his most recent band.
 
Tom Morello has now joined the list of the many celebrities with comics with his release of his 12 issue series called Orchid.
name: Tom Morello

deck: Spanish artist who worked on many classic British comics from Buster, Tiger, Smash! to the Eagle.
description:
Spanish artist Carlos Cruz worked for the Fleetway agency drawing many classic characters, including:

  • Battle (Glory Rider)
  • Buster (Crabbe's Crusaders, Mighty McGinty, George and Dragon)
  • Tiger, Smash! (Moonie's Magic Mate. The Pillater Peril)
  • Eagle (Dan Dare, Bloodfang)
name: Carlos Cruz

deck: Brazilian artist.

deck: Illustrator, cover artist for Dynamite Comics, licensed Wheel of Time artist, comic creator.
description:
My name is Jeremy Saliba, and I love nerdy stuff.

I graduated from the Academy of Art University in 2003 with a BA in Illustration/Animation. Since then I've enjoyed working on a variety of projects - everything from doing concept art for animation to illustrations for comics. I've also been teaching drawing and painting classes at my old alma mater since 2006.

I'm a movie fanatic and a book worm - any form of storytelling sucks me in. I'm a beer enthusiast, my imaginary friend when I was little was Princess Leia, and I will never say no if you ask me to help you move.
name: Jeremy Saliba

deck: Artist
name: Nate Reynolds

deck: British artist best known for his work on Dan Dare.
description: Worked on the Eagle in the 1950s/60s (Heros the Spartan, Fraser of Africa, Dan Dare), TV21 in the 1960s (Thunderbirds, Captain Scarlet), Swift (Robin Hood) and the Garth newspaper strip in the 1970s.
name: Frank Bellamy

deck: Zurich born artist, famous for his painted covers. Worked on War Picture Library, Trigan Empire (for Look and Learn) and Dan Dare (for the Eagle in the 1980s)
description:
Born in Zurich, Switzerland in 1948. Frey moved to Britain in the 1970s and illustrated many classic British comics, including - War Picture Library, Trigan Empire (for Look and Learn), Dan Dare (for the relaunched Eagle in the 1980s) and the Terminal Man for Newsfield Publications computer magazines (also the 1980s).

Between 1984–1994 Frey contributed literally hundreds of cover images and interior art for Newsfield's magazines, principally CRASH and ZZAP!64. His cult comic strip The Terminal Man was republished as a paperback in September 2012, available from Amazon.
name: Oliver Frey

deck: Uk cartoonist.
description:
Created and illustrated Ernie the Eagle for the relaunched Eagle comic. Ernie appeared as a three panel strip in the vast majority of issues.

Also illustrated Eval McNeval, Sally Scowl and other one-off tales for 1980s kids comic - Oink!
name: Dave Follows

deck:
Gerry Embleton is an Anglo-Swiss artist who works internationally. Born in London, England, which remained the hub of his working life until he moved to Switzerland.

Gerry worked on TV21 in the 1960s and was the first artist to draw the new Dan Dare in 1982.
name: Gerry Embleton

aliases:
Lee Harris
Leland Harris
Harris Levey
deck: Penciler and inker for DC's Air-Wave in Detective Comics in the Golden Age.
description: Worked in DC comics during the Golden Age of Comics. He penciled (and sometimes inked) roughly 50 issues of Detective Comics, which date back as far as 1942. He worked alongside legendary greats, such as Jerry Robinson (creator of the Joker), Bob Kane, and Dick Sprang, and Charles Paris. Although his name is Harris Levy, his common pen name was Lee Harris.
name: Harris Levy
